instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No water damage.
No light on charger so I checked <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> and got only 0.32V measured on fuse F7005.
With 100% working DC-IN same issue.

Diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.645V

Any idea where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> died. The charger needs to see a load in order to put out voltage, and if <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> is dead it won't see a load. One way to confirm this is to cut off a good magsafe 85w cable and attach the ends to a DC power supply, set it to 18.5v, and use that as a charger. It won't care if it sees a load. See if you get any change in activity there. 

Also, [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_LlSuV1JX_w[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thank you.

I replaced twice <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and still same issue.
When using magsafe via DC power supply got short 0.8V and 0.64A.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> on gate (pin 6) and source (pin 5) got 0.774V.

Checked <RESISTOR>R7186</RESISTOR> and is correct but <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR> got 1.378K

Removed <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR> and checked and its got 430K.

When <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> removed then got no short.
Got 18.4V on source (pin 5) and 6.42V on gate (pin 6) so thats looks OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So you know you have a short somewhere. Did you check DCIN and PPBUS lines for shorts? Anything heating up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes, there was short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>.
One of the tant-poly caps was shorting.

Replaced that and had light on charger/fan spin for around 15 secs and dead again. 

This time short was on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  and <TRANSISTOR>Q7135</TRANSISTOR> was shorting.

Replaced that and again was ok for 10-15 secs.

Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Make sure there's no liquid near the CPU regulators...<SIGNAL>S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> will short ppbus as well (i.e. you could have several issues on the board). Common on this model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7135</TRANSISTOR> is dying because the ISL is dead or there is a corroded trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
ISL replaced and short gone but still power issue.

On battery: chime, backlight, Apple logo, login screen and shot down.

On battery and 85W charger: light on charger blinking (ON/OFF), fans as well ON/OFF (no chime)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
What is the resistance between pins 17/18 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>?

What is the resistance between pins 27/28 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>?

If answer to those questions is 2.2 and 20.02 respectively, then I would check the soldering of the chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.32V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 17/18 is not right, check traces and resistors.
